patients.description: suspected severe sepsis or septic shock admitted to the ICU

study.intervention: antibiotics were stopped when PCT levels had decreased 90% or more from the initial value (if clinicians agreed) but not before Day 3 (if baseline PCT levels were,1 mg/L) or Day 5 (if baseline PCT levels were >1 mg/L).

outcome.bullet: duration of antibiotic treatment, antibiotic exposure days, days alive without antibiotics
28-day mortality, in-hospital mortality, length of stay in the ICU and hospital, clinical cure, reoccurrence of the initial infection, and nosocomial superinfection

patients.description: surgical intensive care patients with severe sepsis

study.intervention: PCT <1 ng/mL and clinical signs of infection improved: antibiotics discontinued PCT dropped to <35% of the initial concentration within 3 days and clinical signs of infection improved: antibiotics discontinued

patients.description: SICU patients with confirmed or highly suspected bacterial infections and at least two concomitant systemic inflammatory response syndrome criteria

study.intervention: Antibiotics discontinued, if clinical signs and symptoms of infection improved and PCT decreased to <1 ng/ml or the PCT value was >1 ng/ml, but had dropped to 25 to 35% of the initial value over three days.
study.comparison: standard regimen of antibiotics over 8 days

patients.description: critically ill patients with suspected bacterial infections in ICU

study.intervention: predefined algorithms to guide physicians to start or discontinue antibiotics according to serum procalcitonin concentrations; discontinue antibiotics when procalcitonin concentration was less than 80% of the peak concentration or an absolute concentration of less than 0∙5 μg/L was reached.

outcome.bullet: mortality at days 28 and 60 (non-inferiority analysis), and number of days without antibiotics by day 28 (superiority analysis)

percentage of patients with relapse or superinfection (days 1–28); number of days without mechanical ventilation, defi ned as unassisted breathing (days 1–28); SOFA score (days 1, 7, 14, 21, and 28); length of stay in the intensive care unit and hospital; days of exposure to each antibiotic per 1000 inpatient days, defi ned as the number of days (>24 h) of continuous antibiotic treatment (days 1–28); duration of antibiotic treatment according to infection site; and percentage of emerging multidrug-resistant bacteria isolated from specimens taken for routine microbiological assessments (days 1–28).
